data.name: The Deck of Many Things
entries: The {@deck Deck of Many Things|BMT} is one of the best-known magic items in {@style Dungeons & Dragons|small-caps;dnd-font}. Players delight in the possibilities the deck offers, such as suddenly advancing in level or gaining fabulous wealth. Since its introduction, the deck has been associated with physical cards—game props Dungeon Masters could use to build a deck their players drew from. The cards and book you're holding are designed to satisfy this demand in the best way possible, providing a beautiful deck of physical cards DMs and players can handle, shuffle, and draw from when they encounter the {@deck Deck of Many Things|BMT} in their games.

But this deck is much more than that. The deck has been expanded with forty-four new cards DMs can use to build customized versions of the {@deck Deck of Many Things|BMT} for their games. This deck has also been designed for two additional uses:

entries.name: Divination
entries: Dungeon Masters can use the cards for divinatory readings that provide players with clues about the challenges that lie ahead. Divinatory readings are described in the "{@book Divinatory Uses|DMTCRG|1}" section.

entries.name: Generating Adventures
entries: DMs can use the deck to generate adventure ideas and even outline an adventure's starting situation, journey, encounters, and climax. The guidelines for this are found in the "{@book Adventure Spreads|DMTCRG|2}" section and include an example of how the cards can be used to create a story or a dungeon,

entries.name: Customizing Your Deck
entries: The {@i Deck of Many Things} is as old as D&D, first appearing in 1976. That earliest version of the deck had eighteen unnamed cards, and the DM was encouraged to build the deck from ordinary playing cards, Virtually everything about the deck has changed as the game has evolved: the number of cards has increased, the cards have gained names, the names have changed, and the rules have gone back and forth about whether the {@i Deck of Many Things} is an artifact or perhaps even an intelligent item with its own mysterious goals.

What this means for players and DMs is that no definitive version of the {@i Deck of Many Things} exists. Like everything else in D&D the deck is a tool you can customize to suit the needs of your table, You might include all the cards to capture the wild unpredictability of fate, use only cards that fit a certain theme or yield particular results, or select a few specific cards that precisely fit your adventure. You can even invent new cards. You can find examples Of how to customize the deck to suit your table, including card lists, in {@book chapter 2 of The Book of Many Things|BMT|1}.

entries.name: Updates to the Deck
entries: This book, the associated cards, and {@book The Book of Many Things|BMT} include some updates and revisions to the {@item Deck of Many Things|DMG|version of the deck in the Dungeon Master's Guide}:

items: Two cards have been renamed. The card formerly known as the {@card Vizier|Deck of Many Things} is now the {@card Sage|Deck of Many Things|BMT}, and the card previously called the {@card Idiot|Deck of Many Things} is now the {@card Puzzle|Deck of Many Things|BMT}.

In addition to the twenty-two cards of the {@item Deck of Many Things|DMG}, this deck includes an additional forty-four cards, known as the {@deck Deck of Many More Things|BMT}. These sixty-six cards often appear together as a combined deck. The game rules for the new cards appear in {@book chapter 7 of The Book of Many Things|BMT|6}.

entries.name: Card Meanings
entries: The meanings of in individual cards depend on how you're using the deck. If you're using it to represent the {@item Deck of Many Things|BMT} magic item, the game rules for the twenty-two cards that make up the classic deck appear in the {@item Deck of Many Things|DMG|Dungeon Master's Guide} while rules for the forty-four new cards are detailed in {@book chapter 7 of The Book of Many Things|BMT|6}. However, you can change the powers of cards as you see fit.

If you're using the deck for divination or generating adventures, you have two main options for card meanings. The easiest method is to use the literal meaning of the card. In this case, the {@card Dragon|Deck of Many More Things|BMT} card literally suggests a dragon.

For a more nuanced option, the "{@book Reading the Cards|DMTCRG|3}" section presents an array of potential meanings for each card, depending on which way the card is oriented and using signifiers that suggest how the card applies to people or creatures the characters might meet, places they might visit, treasures they might find, and situations they might experience. For example, the {@card Dragon|Deck of Many More Things|BMT} card could refer to a literal dragon, but it might also indicate a dragonborn, a dragon's lair, or someone hoarding treasure.

entries.name: Card Spreads
entries: In addition to having their own meanings, cards take on additional meanings when combined as spreads: arrangements of oracle cards on a surface. With spreads, the order in which cards are drawn and where they're placed in relation to other cards add meaning to a reading. For example, cards drawn earlier in a reading might be interpreted as talking about the past or the start of an adventure, while those drawn later might speak about the future or an adventure's culmination.

data.name: Divinatory Uses
entries: {@i The Deck of Many Things} card set is a wonderful tool for representing fortune-telling encounters in your game, whether characters arc reading the cards for each other or the DM is portraying a non-player character peering into the characters' futures.

entries.name: Divinatory Basics
entries: Traditional readings require two people: a questioner who is looking for answers, and a reader who places the cards in a spread and interprets their meaning. The questioner and reader cooperate to understand the situation the questioner is in and what might be possible in the questioner's future.

Usually, the DM takes on the role of the reader, and a character is the questioner. However, a character might be both questioner and reader, interpreting the cards to answer a question they're asking themself, or a character might perform readings for the others in the party.

entries.name: Choosing Questions
entries: When posing a question using the deck, avoid anything with a simple yes-or-no answer and questions with a specific, factual answer. Instead, ask open-ended questions that might have many answers. Questions like "How can we stop Iuz from conquering all of the Flanaess?" are more suited to the divinatory nature of the cards than "Where is the Eye of Vecna?"

entries.name: Stacking the Deck
entries: The reader should decide what cards to include in the deck for the reading, depending on their goals.

A DM might want to include only cards that reflect the themes of the adventure, or choose the exact cards to display to give the players specific clues. A character reading a nonplayer character's fortune might do the same if they want to trick or manipulate that person, but trusting in fate and including the whole deck is always an option.

entries.name: Performing the Reading
entries: As cards are drawn, take your time interpreting them. Ponder how the cards' possible interpretations might speak to the questioner's memories, experiences, and current situation. The reader should help the questioner look for connections between cards, seeking the story the cards tell as they're brought together.

entries.name: Divinatory Spreads
entries: This section presents three divinatory spreads you can use in your games. These are only a few of many possible spreads: you can use them as a basis for creating your own ways to place and interpret the cards. Customize the spread to suit the question asked and the deck to suit the themes of your game.

entries.name: One-Card Spread
entries: For the simplest reading, draw a single card from the deck. Many readers use this technique in the morning when preparing for a day of adventure. The card they draw presents a message about the day to come, something to use as guidance when the adventure becomes challenging and the way forward unclear. Alternatively, drawing a single card can provide quick guidance concerning an immediate problem or an ongoing situation that has become impossible to ignore.

entries.name: Three-Card Spread
entries: A three-card spread allows the cards to tell a story, as the cards interact with each other and their meanings resonate and connect. This increases the power and usefulness of the cards, but there are many ways to interpret a three-card spread, so it's important to know what you want from the cards before you place them.

The most common form of a three-card spread is to interpret the first card as representing the past, especially forces in the past that are relevant to the question. The second card represents the present situation, and the final card hints at the future.

Alternatively, the first card might represent a problem, the second card an obstacle, and the final card the solution. Or the first card could represent the questioner, the second card another individual, and the third card the relationship between the two.

entries.name: Five-Card Spread
entries: A five-card spread (see diagram 1) allows a question to be answered with great complexity and nuance, as the cards show multiple perspectives and weave an interconnected story, Here's an example of a five-card spread you might use:

items.name: The Quest
items.entry: The first card is the Quest card, which is placed in the center. This represents the adventure itself or the current situation.

items.name: That Which Is Hidden
items.entry: The second card, That Which Is Hidden, is placed to the left of the Quest card. That Which Is Hidden describes things in the questioner's past, elements of the subconscious, hidden enemies, or simply things that have been forgotten or neglected. The forces represented by this card weigh down the questioner and impede completion of the quest.

items.name: That Which Is Needed
items.entry: The third card, That Which Is Needed, is placed to the right of the Quest card. It represents the tools necessary for success on the quest. This might be the help of an ally or a useful item, but it could also stand for knowledge the questioner must acquire to achieve their goal.

items.name: The Challenge
items.entry: The fourth card, the Challenge, is placed below the Quest card and represents the chief obstacle to success: the thing most likely to prevent the questioner from achieving the quest. Use the assets described in That Which Is Needed, while taking precautions against That Which Is Hidden, to overcome whatever the Challenge represents.

items.name: The Outcome
items.entry: Finally, the Outcome is placed above the Quest card. This might represent the culmination of the adventure, but it can also illuminate ramifications or consequences that follow the quest's success or failure.

data.name: Adventure Spreads
entries: An adventure spread is an arrangement of cards from {@deck Deck of Many More Things|DMTCRG|The Deck of Many Things} card set that you can use to craft an adventure for your D&D game. With this method, the cards drawn determine adventure details such as the situation that launches the adventure, challenges the party faces along the way, and the final obstacle the party must overcome. This kind of spread typically uses the full deck, but you can use a smaller set of cards if you want your adventure to focus on particular themes or adversaries.

entries.name: Creating an Adventure Spread
entries: To prepare the deck for creating an adventure spread, shuffle the cards, being sure to rotate some cards as you do so some cards will be upright and others reversed (upside down). Then lay out the top nine cards in a cross pattern, as shown in diagram 2. Each card represents a situation, person, creature, location, or treasure in the adventure, using the signifiers for each card described in the "{@book Reading the Cards|DMTCRG|3}" section. You can pick any of a card's signifiers for any of the positions in the diagram, so let your imagination wander and build a story that excites you. Treat the cards placed sideways as upright if the top of the card is on the left and as reversed if the top is on the right.
Lay out the cards in this order:

items.name: 1: Party Gathers
items.entry: This card represents the situation the characters are in before the adventure starts. It might be a place where they meet, a person they're visiting, a treasure they're all drawn to for different reasons, or a dangerous creature unrelated to the adventure to follow.

items.name: 2: Adventure Begins
items.entry: Place this card across the first card to represent how the adventure starts. It might be a situation that starts the action, an individual who gives the adventurers a quest, or an attack by a creature that prompts the party to follow it to its lair.

items.name: 3: Journey
items.entry: To the right of the first card, place a card that describes the transition from the introduction to the adventure location—probably a person, creature, or location the characters encounter along the way.

items.name: 4: Entrance
items.entry: Draw a card and place it to the right of the Journey card. This card describes the entrance to the adventure location. It might represent a creature that guards the entrance or the physical details of the entrance itself.

items.name: 5, 6, 7: Challenges
items.entry: These three cards describe the primary challenges the characters must face in the adventure. They might be creatures, people, or situations. Arrange these cards in a vertical line to the right of the Entrance card. You can draw additional cards if you want more than three challenges, or fewer cards for a shorter session.

items.name: 8: Treasure
items.entry: This card, placed to the right of the Challenge cards, describes a treasure that is the ultimate goal or reward of the adventure.

items.name: 9: Guardian
items.entry: Place this card across the Treasure card to describe the final obstacle the characters must overcome to achieve their goal and claim the Treasure. It's typically a creature but can also be a situation.

entries.name: Example
entries: Jennifer is running a game for her players next week, and she doesn't have an adventure planned. She decides to use The {@deck Deck of Many More Things|DMTCRG|Deck of Many Things} card set to generate adventure ideas. After shuffling the deck, she places cards as shown in diagram 3. Here's the adventure she creates: if a creature's name is bold, its stat block appears in the {@book Monster Manual|MM} unless otherwise stated:

items.name: 1: Party Gathers
items.entry: Jennifer's first card is the {@card Jester|Deck of Many More Things|DMTCRG} upright. She likes the idea of starting off in a fairground. The characters can engage in carnival games before the action starts.

items.name: 2: Adventure Begins
items.entry: Jennifer draws the {@card Comet|Deck of Many More Things|DMTCRG} card reversed, whose creature signifier suggests the fairground is overrun by small creatures fleeing from a rampaging monster. She decides the creatures are panicked {@creature goblin|MM|goblins}; they're not malicious or intent on fighting. but their arrival cre- ates chaos. Jennifer isn't sure what the monster is yet, but it should be a threat that demands heroic action from the characters.

items.name: 3: Journey
items.entry: Jennifer draws the {@card Fool|Deck of Many More Things|DMTCRG} card reversed. She opts to use the person signifier—a con artist—for an encounter during the journey. As the characters travel to where the rampaging monster was last seen. they're targeted by a con artist who pretends to be a refugee displaced by the monster. Jennifer decides this con artist is a {@creature bard|MPMM} (whose stat block appears in Mordenkainen Presents: Monsters of the Multiverse) who uses the {@spell Charm Person} and {@spell Sleep} spells to try to overcome the characters and steal their belongings.

items.name: 4: Entrance
items.entry: When determining the lair of the rampaging monster, Jennifer draws the {@card Euryale|Deck of Many More Things|DMTCRG} card reversed. This card's place signifier could be a simple underground cavern, but Jennifer finds the idea of a place with narrow windows or arrow slits more evocative. She envisions a gatehouse built by the fleeing goblins, which the rampaging monster has driven them from. Because the gatehouse is built for goblins, the ceilings are low and the doorways narrow, posing interesting tactical challenges for the characters as they explore.

items.name: 5: Challenge
items.entry: For the first challenge, Jennifer draws the {@card Donjon|Deck of Many More Things|DMTCRG} card reversed, which indicates a creature that has escaped captivity or gone feral. She decides the goblins kept a pack of {@creature worg|MM|worgs} in their gatehouse, and now the hungry worgs prowl the corridors. While the worgs are likely to attack, clever players might be able to get past them non-violently, perhaps by feeding them or speaking to them in a language they know (such as {@language Goblin}).

items.name: 6: Challenge
items.entry: For the second challenge, Jennifer draws the {@card Fates|Deck of Many More Things|DMTCRG} card, opting to use a {@creature green hag|MM} investigating the gatehouse with an eye toward making it her new home. The hag warns the characters that fate isn't on their side, but she won't attack unless the adventurers force her hand.

items.name: 7: Challenge
items.entry: The third challenge is the {@card Flames|Deck of Many More Things|DMTCRG} card reversed, which suggests another creature fleeing from a larger or more dangerous creature, namely the rampaging monster at the heart of the adventure. Jennifer figures there must be goblins in the gatehouse, perhaps in a hastily fortified chamber; she creates an encounter using a {@creature goblin boss|MM} and enough additional goblins to give the characters a fight. The goblin boss won't be satisfied until the adventurers, the hag, and the rampaging monster are all gone from the gatehouse. The adventurers can resolve this by clearing out the monster and the hag, winning the grudging appreciation of the goblin boss.

items.name: 8: Treasure
items.entry: 8: Treasure. Jennifer draws the {@card Gem|Deck of Many More Things|DMTCRG} card for the adventure's reward, which indicates precious gemstones or a magical gem. She decides a treasury in the gatehouse has a store of precious gemstones; she uses the tables in the Dungeon Master's Guide to generate a treasure hoard of gems appropriate for the characters. She also adds a {@item Spell Gem|OotA} (a magic item described in Out of the Abyss) to make the treasure more memorable.

items.name: 9: Guardian
items.entry: For the Guardian card. Jennifer draws the {@card Balance|Deck of Many More Things|DMTCRG} card, suggesting an impartial enemy like a Construct or Beast. After a quick search of the Monster Manual, Jennifer decides that a {@creature helmed horror|MM} is perfect for her party. She decides the goblins must've fought the helmed horror's creator, and now the Construct is rampaging through the gatehouse to satisfy its creator's final command: "Avenge me!" Jennifer places the {@item Spell Gem|OotA} in the helmed horror's helmet; the Construct can use this gem, but without its creator to recharge it, that's a trick that works only once, If the heroes defeat the helmed horror, they can claim the {@item Spell Gem|OotA} for themselves.

entries.name: Variant: Dungeon Spread
entries: A dungeon spread is a simpler version of an adventure spread that's optimized for quickly building dungeon-focused adventures. In this variant, you divide The {@deck Deck of Many More Things|DMTCRG|Deck of Many Things} card set into three separate decks: a {@deck locations deck|DMTCRG}, a {@deck features deck|DMTCRG}, and an optional {@deck story deck|DMTCRG}. For simplicity, use the literal meanings of the cards in the locations and features decks; these cards are straightforward descriptions of potential locations and of the creatures, treasures, and other features characters might find in these locations.

If you want to create a prelude to the dungeon, use the optional steps that call for the story deck, and give those cards their full range of symbolic meaning as discussed in the "{@book Reading the Cards|DMTCRG|3}" section. If you'd rather dive straight into the action, you can skip those steps and omit the story deck.
Using these separate decks, lay out the cards in a slightly modified adventure spread:

items.name: 1: Party Gathers (Optional)
items.entry: Draw a card from the {@deck story deck|DMTCRG} to represent the situation the characters are in before the adventure starts.

items.name: 2: Adventure Begins (Optional)
items.entry: Draw a card from the {@deck story deck|DMTCRG} to represent the situation that starts off the adventure.

items.name: 3: Journey (Optional)
items.entry: Draw a card from the {@deck story deck|DMTCRG} to represent the journey to the dungeon.

items.name: 4: Entrance
items.entry: Draw a card from the {@deck locations deck|DMTCRG} to determine the dungeon's location, then place a card from the {@deck features deck|DMTCRG} across it to describe a feature found at the entrance.

items.name: 5, 6, 7: Challenges
items.entry: Decide how many challenges you want the adventurers to encounter before reaching the treasure and its guardian. For each challenge, draw a card from the {@deck locations deck|DMTCRG} to describe the challenge's location, then place a card from the {@deck features deck|DMTCRG} across it to describe the challenge itself.

items.name: 8: Treasure
items.entry: Draw a card from the {@deck features deck|DMTCRG} to describe the treasure at the end of the dungeon.

items.name: 9: Guardian
items.entry: Finally, draw a card from the {@deck features deck|DMTCRG} to represent the guardian of the treasure and a card from the {@deck locations deck|DMTCRG} to describe where the treasure and its guardian can bc found.

entries.name: Using an Adventure Spread During Play
entries: In addition to using an adventure spread to plan your adventures, you can also use it during play, simultaneously giving the players a glimpse into the future and planning their adventure. An easy way to do this is to plan a social encounter with a fortune teller near the end of a session or play. (The {@table Using an Adventure Spread During Play; Fortune Tellers|DMTCRG|Fortune Tellers} table suggests descriptions for seers.) Talking the role of the fortune teller, lay out the cards in an adventure spread in view of your players, narrating as you go.

When your players speculate on the meaning of the cards, use their ideas to interpret the spread. If you embrace their guesses, your players can enjoy feeling clever for figuring out the "real" meaning of the reading—when in fact they've helped create it. You might also deliberately confound your players by steering away from their interpretations as you build the adventure.

entries.caption: Fortune Tellers
rows: An entertainer at a street fair or civic festival, who emphasizes that this card reading is "for entertainment purposes only"
A professional fortune teller with a shop in a small town, who tries to inject the reading with elements of romance
A seer in a temple, whose eyes are closed throughout the reading and who couches everything in terms of the will of a certain god
A hag who cackles gleefully at every hint of danger or destruction in the reading
A haunted deck of cards that lays itself out and narrates the reading in a distant, ghostly echo
A member of the {@book Heralds of the Comet|BMT|11|Heralds of the Comet} (an apocalyptic cult described in The Book of Many Things), who stresses danger and destruction in the reading

entries: When performing this reading, introduce each card as you place it in the spread (you can use the suggested wordings below). Briefly describe the relevant signifier for the card, but don't include any specific examples listed in the card descriptions:

items.name: 1: Party Gathers
items.entry: "This is where your future begins." Reveal the card, then choose a signifier for the card and describe it to the players,

items.name: 2: Adventure Begins
items.entry: "Then someone or something intervenes, leading you down a new path." Reveal the card, then choose a signifier, describing it to the players as an agent of change.

items.name: 3: Journey
items.entry: "As you take your first steps into the future, forces will oppose you." Reveal the card and describe the forces that will oppose the characters on their journey. Again, remain vague.

items.name: 4: Entrance
items.entry: "Now you stand on the threshold of what is to come." Reveal the card and describe the place where the characters' future will unfold.

items.name: 5, 6, 7: Challenges
items.entry: "Within this place, you will face challenges." Reveal the cards one at a time. For each one, choose the creature, the person, or the situation and describe it—or talk about the general meaning of the card and the range of challenges it refers to.

items.name: 8: Treasure
items.entry: "Beyond these challenges lies the goal you seek," Reveal the card and describe the treasure that awaits, Since treasures can include monetary treasure, art objects, and magic items, you might want to describe the general meaning of the card and the range of things it can refer to rather than specifying one kind of treasure.

items.name: 9: Guardian
items.entry: "One final guardian stands between you and the object of your quest." Reveal the card, choose either the creature or the situation. and describe it to the players.

data.name: Reading the Cards
entries: The following pages describe the meanings of the sixty-six cards in The {@deck Deck of Many Things|BMT} card set. For each card, there's an illustration and a description of the symbols depicted, a summary of the card's overall meaning, and explanations of what the card might signify in both upright and reversed (upside-down) positions. Each position includes five possible signifiers to choose from based on the situation:

items: A {@b person}, with suggestions regarding personality traits or the situation the person is in. A person can be any kind of Humanoid, but might also be a Giant, a Dragon, or any other creature with a personality and the ability to interact with characters. This signifier might also describe something about the person for whom a card reading is being done.
A {@b creature or trap} characters might encounter.
A {@b place}, which can suggest a specific location or a kind of location.
A {@b treasure}, either something of monetary value or a magic item.
A {@b situation}—an interaction or circumstance that characters might be asked to help address.

entries: When using the cards for divinatory readings, you can use cards' overall meaning or draw on any signifiers that make sense for your game. The adventure spreads typically draw on all five kinds of signifiers to build the skeleton of an adventure.

entries.name: Aberration
entries: {@i A beholder hovers in a cluttered laboratory. The Aberration card embodies things contrary to nature.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: Someone with a distorted view of reality, perhaps a {@creature cultist} or a {@creature warlock of the Great Old One|MPMM}; perhaps simply an eccentric person with a nonconformist style.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature corrupted by the influence of the Far Realm, or an Aberration.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where the laws of physics or magic are suspended or distorted.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object that reflects a warped view of reality, or a magic item made by Aberrations.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An incursion of energy or creatures from the Far Realm or the deep Underdark.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person (perhaps a {@creature druid}) dedicated to preserving nature against corrupting influences.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that has resisted the corruption of its nature, or a trap that deals psychic damage.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where nature has overgrown the remnants of a corrupting influence.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting the triumph of nature over corruption, or a magic item useful against Aberrations (such as a {@item Ring of Mind Shielding}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: People or creatures fighting against the influence of Aberrations.

entries.name: Balance
entries: {@i A set of scales holds day and night in balance. This card deals with many aspects of balance, or with things being out of balance.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A fair-minded person who can see multiple perspectives and judge impartially.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A trap, a Beast, a Construct, or an otherwise impartial foe.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where different forces exist in balance—such as a civilization in balance with nature, a land in balance with water, or chaos in balance with order.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure with value to two competing factions, or with two equal magical powers.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation where maintaining balance is important: keeping rivals satisfied, preserving the balance of power among different authorities, or rejecting false dichotomies and forced choices.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A judgmental or biased person willfully ignoring one perspective in favor of another.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Celestial, a Fiend, or some other creature strongly associated with a particular alignment or ideology.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where the balance of elemental or natural forces has been upset, with negative consequences.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure valuable only to certain people, or that can be used only in a very specific way.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Something being over- or undervalued.

entries.name: Beast
entries: {@i The Beast card points to creatures of the animal kingdom and foul, cruel, or bad-tempered behavior in people.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who avoids the comforts of civilization or indulges predatory attitudes.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Beast, or a similar creature (such as a Fey or a Monstrosity) that is animal-like; alternatively, a pit or other confined space with a trapped animal within.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where animals roam freely.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure that incorporates fur, feathers, bones, or claws from a Beast, or a magic item that allows transformation into a Beast (such as a {@item Cloak of the Bat} or {@item Staff of the Python}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation involving hunting animals or animals preying on people.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who fiercely represses urges they deem "bestial" in themselves or others.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A domesticated animal or a familiar.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where animals are contained, such as a farm or a zoo.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An ornate saddle, a goad, or another item related to the use of domestic animals, or a magic item that allows control of Beasts (such as a {@item Potion of Animal Friendship}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Domestic animals rebelling against people's control.

entries.name: Book
entries: {@i An enormous book rests among scrolls and parchment, with a quill and ink nearby. The Book card embodies written information.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A writer, poet, or compulsive note-taker.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that keeps an exhaustive diary in some form, or that seeks a scribe to record its deeds.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A scriptorium or printing press.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A valuable or magical pen, an ink vial, or a set of pigments (such as {@item Nolzur's Marvelous Pigments}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that requires gleaning information from written clues.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A well-educated person who reads often.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A trap involving written runes (such as a {@spell Glyph of Warding} or {@spell Symbol} spell).

items.name: Place
items.entry: A library or another storehouse of written knowledge.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A valuable or magical written work, such as a book or scroll.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Secrets that should never have been discovered but were written down.

entries.name: Bridge
entries: {@i A stone bridge arcs across a waterway. A shadowy figure lurks under the bridge, only its gleaming eyes clearly visible. This card reflects the effort required to overcome obstacles.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A mediator who enjoys helping others overcome misunderstandings or grievances.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: Someone who coordinates the efforts of different kinds of creatures, such as a {@creature mind flayer} mastermind using {@creature grimlock|MM|grimlocks} and {@creature troll|MM|trolls} as agents.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A bridge across a river or chasm.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting a bridge, or a magic item intended to help overcome obstacles (such as {@item Boots of Striding and Springing}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An urgent need for bridges between long-opposed factions.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who is part of a longstanding feud between two families or groups.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that lairs near, on, or under a bridge and either collects tolls from those using the bridge or tries to eat them.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A river or chasm with no bridge, or where the bridge is unsafe or has collapsed.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting walls, barriers. or a labyrinth; alternatively, a magic item that creates magical walls (such as a {@item Cube of Force}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Open conflict between two families or groups.

entries.name: Campfire
entries: {@i A large campfire offers safety and comfort in the night. This card suggests a need for rest.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person on vacation, enjoying time away from work and pursuing activities they enjoy.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that alternates brief periods of activity with long periods of rest (as many reptiles and Dragons do); alternatively, a trap that requires a long time to reset between activations.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place recently used as a campsite.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting a peaceful scene, or a magic item that facilitates safe rest (such as a {@item Rod of Security}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A period of rest in the middle of a journey or an adventure.

items.name: Person
items.entry: An exhausted person.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature immune to {@condition exhaustion} (such as an angel, a golem, an Ooze, or an Undead), or a trap or hazard with a constant, ongoing effect.

items.name: Place
items.entry: Somewhere not conducive to rest, such as a busy marketplace active at all hours.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object that suggests frenetic activity, or a magic item that helps its user remain alert (such as a {@item Sentinel Shield}),

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that demands unrelenting activity.

entries.name: Cavern
entries: {@i A vast cavern is adorned with glowing fungi and striking stone formations. The Cavern card suggests exploration and delving into hidden secrets.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who asks probing questions but shares little.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature (such as a {@creature piercer} or a {@creature roper}) that mimics the features of natural caverns.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A cavern or a cavernous building such as a large temple.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A geode, jewelry made from gems and precious metals, or a magic item that grants {@sense darkvision} (such as {@item Goggles of Night}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that requires delving into hidden motivations and secrets.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who lives for the moment, avoiding introspection.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that swallows prey whole, or a trap that causes a ceiling or roof to collapse.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A small niche or cave.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object that lacks a sense of depth or perspective.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Everyone's motivations exposed for all to see.

entries.name: Celestial
entries: {@i A beautiful couatl twines through the clouds. This card suggests the involvement of celestial beings and service to the divine.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A devout person who looks for miracles and the presence of the divine in all parts of life.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Celestial or other creature that has connections to the gods, or a trap that deals radiant damage.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A location on the upper planes, or a place suffused with their influence.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting angels or other Celestials, treasure from the Upper Planes, or magic items made by Celestials.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Communication between the Upper Planes and the Material Plane—perhaps in dreams or visions, or with Celestials as intermediaries.

items.name: Person
items.entry: Someone who carries a grudge over a real or perceived injury caused by a god or Celestial.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A fallen Celestial or similar creature that has lost its connection to the divine,

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place intended to ward off Celestials and influence from the Upper Planes.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure depicting a Celestial's fall, or a magic item useful against Celestials.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation involving Celestials' unwelcome interference in mortal affairs.

entries.name: Comet
entries: {@i A comet with an enormous tail streaks across the winter sky at night, outshining the stars. The Comet card brings dire warnings or devastation.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A serious person with a gloomy outlook, perhaps carrying bad news.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature regarded as an ill omen, or signs that a dire creature approaches; alternatively, a trap marked by clear signs, perhaps surrounded by the corpses of its victims.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place with a connection to astronomical events: perhaps an observatory or a meteorite's crater.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure that carries a curse, or one whose power is destined to be used for destructive ends.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A crisis about to spiral out of control.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who is grieving or delights in the suffering of others.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: The destruction left in the wake ofa rampaging creature, or smaller creatures fleeing from a larger one.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A ruin where a terrible event occurred in the past and that might now be haunted.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: . A treasure formed or shaped by disaster, bloodstained or haunted by former owners: alternatively, something good arising from a bad situation.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: The calm after a devastating storm: a situation where people are reeling from awful news or events.

entries.name: Construct
entries: {@i A modron wields a wrench in the interior of a clockwork machine. This card signifies things made by hand, including Constructs.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: An artisan who delights in handcrafted goods.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A construct, particularly designed to be animated (like a golem) as opposed to an ordinary object (like a {@creature animated broom|CM|broom} or {@creature rug of smothering|MM|rug}) that has been animated.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A workshop or art studio.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An exquisitely crafted art object (especially one with practical use) or magical tools.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An artisan attempting to bring a construct to life.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who scorns the idea of working with their hands.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature able to destroy buildings and objects, such as one with the Siege Monster trait.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A garbage heap or another place where objects are discarded.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An object fashioned with minimum ation of its raw materials, or a magic item useful against Constructs (such as a {@item Mace of Smiting}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A rueful artisan attempting to destroy a Construct that has broken free of all restraint.

entries.name: Corpse
entries: {@i An adventurer lies dead in a dungeon hallway, pierced by arrows. The Corpse card embodies decay and corruption.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: An evil person whose morality has rotted away.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A zombie or similar corporeal Undead whose flesh is decaying, or a trapped corpse.

items.name: Place
items.entry: Somewhere things are left to rot, such as a graveyard or charnel house.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting dead bodies, a corpse just starting to decay, or a magic item that causes decay (such as a {@item Staff of Withering}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An organization or institution overwhelmed by corruption.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A good person who remains uncorrupted despite being surrounded by wickedness.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: An Ooze or fungus creature that facilitates the decomposition of corpses.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where fungus grows abundantly on a diet of rotting flesh.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure that remains uncorrupted in the midst of rot.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An attempt to corrupt a respected and noble organization.

entries.name: Crossroads
entries: {@i A signpost points in many directions at a crossroads. The Crossroads cards warns of a difficult but necessary decision.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person agonizing about a difficult decision or who regrets a recent decision.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that induces confusion or erratic behavior (such as an {@creature umber hulk}).

items.name: Place
items.entry: A crossroads, or a settlement where trade routes cross.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object that depicts a crossroads or cross patterns, or a magic item with multiple properties or uses (such as a staff).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A choice between options that are equally appealing—or equally disastrous.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who refuses to make decisions, relying instead on inaction or random determination.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that prevents others from acting (such as a {@creature ghoul}).

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place that constrains movement, such as a narrow ravine or passage.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object featuring overlapping circular patterns, or a magic item that does only does one thing a limited number of times (such as a wand).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation stemming from someone's refusal to act or choose.

entries.name: Donjon
entries: {@i Underground stairs lead to a heavy door made of iron bars. This card represents both imprisonment and freedom.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A prisoner, or a person who feels trapped.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that grapples or swallows prey whole.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place of imprisonment, such as a literal dungeon or a menagerie.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure locked in a vault, or magic with the power to bind or imprison.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An impasse, a situation that threatens someone's freedom, or a situation where someone's indecision is keeping everyone in suspense.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A recently freed or escaped prisoner, or a free thinker who rejects social norms.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that has escaped from captivity or gone feral.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A prison broken open, or a place associated with liberation (such as a monument commemorating emancipation).

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure that once held a being captive, such as an {@item Efreeti Bottle} that has lost its magic or an empty {@item Iron Flask}.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that requires creative solutions, or an effort to free people or creatures from captivity.

entries.name: Door
entries: {@i A large wooden door bars the path ahead. The card offers an opportunity to change.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: Someone trying to make amends for past misdeeds and adopt a better way of life.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that changes form, or a trapped door.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A door, an open doorway, or a passage from one place to another.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object that looks very different from various perspectives, or a magic item that creates portals or allows teleportation (such as an {@item Amulet of the Planes}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An opportunity to deal with a situation differently than you have in the past.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who keeps repeating the same mistakes and misdeeds.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that causes its prey or enemies to change, such as a lycanthrope or slaad.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A locked door or barricaded passage.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A jeweled chest or lockbox, or a magic item that resists change (such as an {@item Immovable Rod}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that keeps recurring.

entries.name: Dragon
entries: {@i A menacing red dragon perches atop its treasure hoard inside a cave. This card can point to things connected to Dragons, but it also suggests hoarding, reed, and places rich in magical energy.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A dragonborn, a person who uses draconic magic, a person who is fascinated by dragons, or a person who hoards wealth or other goods.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Dragon or similar creature.

items.name: Place
items.entry: The lair of a Dragon or some other impressive creature, or a site of great magical power.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: Large quantities of treasure, though not necessarily of great monetary value (for example, many copper coins or a large collection of cheap statuettes).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Someone hoarding resources that are widely needed or desired.

items.name: Person
items.entry: Someone with a grudge against a particular Dragon or against Dragons in general.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A dracolich or another Undead dragon, a Construct that resembles a Dragon, or another Dragon-like creature.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where a Dragon was slain, leaving a magical or physical scar on the land.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting the death of a Dragon, or a magic item useful against Dragons (such as a {@item Dragon Slayer}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A group that plans to drive a Dragon from its lair, steal from its hoard, or kill it.

entries.name: Elemental
entries: {@i A hungry Xorn feeds in an Underdark cavern. This card suggests an Elemental creature or reducing a thing to its essence.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who uses magic tied to the elements or who is cartoonishly two-dimensional.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: An Elemental creature, or a creature that uses air, earth, fire, or water magic.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place influenced by the Elemental Planes or associated with an element (such as a cave, a mountain, a volcano, or a river).

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object that incorporates material from an Elemental Plane or imagery of the elements, or a magic item that conjures or controls Elementals (such as a {@item Ring of Elemental Command}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Forces from the Elemental Planes spilling into the world.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person driven by an internal conflict between two opposed tendencies or influences.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature (such as a mephit) that combines the substance of two Elemental Planes, or creatures from opposing Elemental Planes.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where forces of the Elemental Planes are in opposition to each other.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object that incorporates material from multiple Elemental Planes or imagery of elements in opposition; a magic item useful against Elementals.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Opposed forces from two or more Elemental Planes entering the world.

entries.name: Euryale
entries: {@i A female medusa with a serpentine tail instead of legs is surrounded by flowers and herbs. The Euryale card points to vision, insight, and observation,}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who observes without becoming involved or attached,

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A {@creature medusa} or another creature with the power to petrify or a gaze attack.

items.name: Place
items.entry: Somewhere with commanding views, such as a watchtower or a high promontory.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A landscape painting or tapestry, or a magic item that enhances vision (such as {@item Goggles of Night}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that rewards or requires careful observation, such as a surveillance operation.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A nosy person vho inserts themself into situations where they don't belong.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature made of or associated with stone.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place with narrow windows (perhaps arrow slits) or with a limited view, perhaps underground.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A valuable sculpture or statue, a gemstone, or a magic item made from stone, such as a {@item Figurine of Wondrous Power}.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation arising from people's unwillingness to observe things as they are, or their tendency to project their own feelings and opinions onto others.

entries.name: Expert
entries: {@i A bard plays a musical instrument. This card implies expertise, rightly or wrongly applied.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person (perhaps a bard, a rogue, a ranger, or an artificer) with exactly the right skills for the task at hand.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature with abilities similar to those of a bard, ranger, or rogue, such as expertise in one or more skills.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place (such as a guild hall) where skilled folk gather to share their expertise.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure with practical use, such as a musical instrument or a tool.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that requires and rewards the expert application of practical skills.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who believes themself an expert but isn't actually helpful.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that relies on brute strength instead of skill or stealth.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where children learn the basics of useful skills.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A wildly impractical treasure with no actual use, unwieldy to wear or display.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation stemming from someone's expertise being overlooked or ignored.

entries.name: Fates
entries: {@i Three sisters weave, measure, and cut the threads of fate. This card explores the repercussions of decisions and reflects on the past.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person perhaps nearing the end of their life, troubled by past mistakes or reflecting on prior decisions.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A supernatural creature connected to fate, such as a Celestial, modron, or hag.

items.name: Place
items.entry: Somewhere meant for literal or metaphorical reflection, such as a room full of mirrors, a still mountain lake, a monastery, a hermitage, or a library.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An ornate or magical mirror, tapestry, or other woven treasure; alternatively, magic that can alter fate.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation ordained by fate, perhaps involving a supernatural punishment or reward.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person driven by the desire to escape whatever fate has in store.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature strongly associated with chaos, such as a demon or a slaad.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place that discourages reflection, such as a dark place or a noisy, busy one.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting the effort to escape fate, or a magic item powered by chaos.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An unjust situation where evil is rewarded and good is punished.

entries.name: Fey
entries: {@i A blink dog runs through the wild. When upright; this card can refer to a Fey creature or a sense of whimsy; reversed, it points to the gloomy Shadowfell.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person with Fey ancestry or some other connection to the Fey (such as a {@creature warlock of the Archfey|MPMM}), or a person with a whimsical sense of humor.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Fey creature, or some other creature with connections to the Feywild.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place in the Feywild, somewhere that allows passage to the Feywild, or a location where Fey magic is active.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting Fey or the Feywild, or a magic item made by Fey.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An absurd situation that shouldn't be taken too seriously.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A gloomy person with no sense of humor, or a person who uses shadow-based magic.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature from the Shadowfell, or one transformed by shadow energy (such as a shadow dragon).

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place in the Shadowfell, somewhere that allows passage to the Shadowfell, or a location where shadow magic is active.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting the Shadowfell, or a magic item that uses shadow magic.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A gloomy situation that offers little hope of success or escape.

entries.name: Fiend
entries: {@i A balor strikes from the depths of the Abyss. This card alludes to an actual Fiend or the forces of the Lower Planes.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A tiefling, {@creature warlock of the Fiend|MPMM}, member of a Fiend-worshiping cult, or person who seeks to manipulate others into harmful contracts.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Fiend of any sort.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place on the Lower Planes, or a location suffused with their influence.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting Fiends, treasure from the Lower Planes, or magic items made by Fiends.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Interaction between the Lower Planes and the Material Plane perhaps an infernal bargain or demonic destruction.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who carries a grudge over a real or perceived injury caused by a Fiend, or a person trapped in a bargain with a Fiend.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A redeemed Fiend or similar creature that has lost its connection to the Lower Planes.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place intended to ward off Fiends and influence from the Lower Planes.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure depicting a Fiend's redemption, or a magic item useful against Fiends.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation involving Fiends' unwelcome interference in mortal affairs.

entries.name: Flames
entries: {@i A chain devil, wreathed in flames, looks menacing and angry. The Flames card brings enemies and vengeance.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person carrying a bitter, possibly violent, grudge that poisons their outlook.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Fiend, a vengeful Undead (such as a {@creature ghost} or {@creature revenant}), or a creature dedicated to pursuing designated prey (such as an {@creature invisible stalker}).

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place of bloodshed, or a place with a connection to the Lower Planes.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure that has been the subject of intense discord or rivalry, or a magic item originating on the Lower Planes.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A deep-seated enmity that clouds the judgment of those involved, or someone's thirst for revenge.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who is being hunted or persecuted unjustly.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature fleeing from a larger or more dangerous foe.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place of sanctuary for refugees and fugitives.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure symbolizing or commemorating the end of a feud or war, or a magic item that can charm or calm creatures (such as a {@item Rod of Rulership}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Unjust persecution or prejudicial hatred.

entries.name: Fool
entries: {@i A person walks down a path, unwittingly dropping items along the way. The Fool card represents innocence.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: An innocent or naive person blissfully ignorant of the world's sinister side, possibly a child.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A naive Celestial or a flighty Fey, or a trap with a simple or obvious means of avoiding it.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place connected with children, such as a nursery, an orphanage, or a school.s

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A portrait of a child, jewelry meant for a child, or a magic item connected to the Upper Planes.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation requiring trust, honesty, and a leap of faith.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A con artist who preys on the innocent and gullible while presenting a trustworthy facade.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that changes shape to appear harmless so it can get close to its prey, or a trap that is difficult to avoid.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place tied to the loss of innocence, such as a harsh orphanage or exploitative workhouse.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure stolen from a child or naive person, or magic intended to deceive (such as a {@item Hat of Disguise}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A guileless person being manipulated by schemers.

entries.name: Gem
entries: {@i A large, faceted gemstone set in intricate filigree gleams invitingly. The Gem card brings vast wealth.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: Someone who inherited wealth or whose wealth is the result of good fortune.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature connected with wealth, such as a Dragon or a {@creature Xorn}, or a treasure that doubles as a trap.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A mine or a treasure vault.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A valuable treasure or a magical gem.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation driven by greed, such as siblings vying for an inheritance or someone hunting for a lost treasure.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who has lost wealth or power through a stroke of bad luck.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A trap or creature that uses the appearance of treasure as bait, such as a {@creature mimic}.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place associated with poverty, such as a tenement or slum.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An item that appears valuable but isn't, or a magic item with a curse.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation stemming from the loss of wealth, such as a person trying to recover money given to a con artist or stolen by a thief.

entries.name: Giant
entries: {@i A hungry troll lurks in a forest clearing. The Giant card indicates something very large or that looms large in one's perception.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A family member, a dear friend, or another personally important individual; alternatively, a very tall person.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Giant, a giant animal, or another big creature.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place constructed by Giants, or a place of great personal significance.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure made by Giants, or one of great sentimental value,

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Someone attaching outsize importance to one element of the situation, to the neglect of other factors.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who seems insignificant.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Tiny creature that's a greater threat than its size suggests.

items.name: Place
items.entry: Somewhere destroyed by Giants.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure depicting or commemorating the slaying of a Giant, or a magic item useful against Giants (such as a {@item Giant Slayer}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Someone unable or unwilling to recognize the importance of a critical factor.

entries.name: Humanoid
entries: {@i Kobolds set a trap in their cave lair. This card points to the importance of empathy in relationships with other people.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: An empathetic person who's deeply concerned about the suffering of others.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A shapeshifter that takes on Humanoid appearance to blend in, perhaps to learn from them or to influence them toward good.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where diverse people live together in harmony.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure representing the collaboration of different artisans (such as a finely cut gem set in exquisite jewelry), or a magic item that facilitates peace and understanding.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that calls for empathy and compassion if it's to be resolved without violence.

items.name: Person
items.entry: Someone who feels no empathy for others.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A shapeshifter that takes on Humanoid appearance to prey on Humanoids.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where people live apart from others, by choice or by force (such as a monastery or a cultural enclave).

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting or celebrating war; alternatively, a magic item made to be used in war, or that is especially useful against Humanoids.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A violent situation arising from a lack of empathy.

entries.name: Jester
entries: {@i A person wearing jester's motley and holding a staff rests his foot on a skull. This card deals with the relationship between humor and misfortune.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: An optimistic person who laughs at their own misfortune.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: o A monster some consider silly, such as a {@creature flumph}, an {@creature owlbear}, or a {@creature gelatinous cube}.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place dedicated to amusement, such as a fairground or a feasting hall.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A humorous art object or magic item, such as a {@item Wand of Wonder}.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A hilarious situation stemming from miscommunication and misplaced assumptions.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who laughs at the misfortunes of others.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature with an unsettling laugh, such as a {@creature gnoll} or {@creature hyena}, or a creature with a cruel sense of humor.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place associated with cruelty and pain, such as a torture chamber.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting pain or humiliation, or a magic item meant to inflict pain (such as a {@item Sword of Wounding}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: One misfortune piling on another in a way that would be humorous—if it weren't disastrous.

entries.name: Key
entries: {@i This large metal key is bizarrely complicated. The Key card represents the perfect solution to a problem or having the right tool for the job.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person with the skills or tools needed to solve the current problem.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that preys on the party's weaknesses, or a trap that can be disarmed only with a key.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place through which only certain people are allowed to pass, or where a key is required.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A magic item needed to overcome an obstacle or defeat an enemy, or the means to unlock a treasure (such as a {@item Chime of Opening}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that be resolved successfully only by taking a specific action.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person ill equipped for the challenges they face.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature with vulnerabilities, or a trap that's bizarrely complex.

items.name: Place
items.entry: An open and easily accessed place.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure in a locked container, or magic that slows creatures.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that can be successfully resolved in many ways.

entries.name: Knight
entries: {@i A knight formed of folded cards offers a sword also made from cards. The Knight card signifies trust and loyalty.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A trustworthy person who _honors their commitments.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature bound by oaths or who serves someone else.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place of sanctuary, where strong traditions protect those who take shelter inside.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure celebrating or commemorating an oath (such as a wedding ring), or magic weapons or armor associated with knights or paladins.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that requires loyalty in one's companions and faithfulness to them.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who can't be trusted, or a traitor posing as a loyal friend.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A knight who has failed to live up to their code of honor (such as a {@creature death knight}).

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where a great betrayal took place, or a location with treacherous terrain or traps.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure that carries a hidden curse, or a magic item that fails when it's needed most.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation involving the betrayal of trust, or rampant suspicion.

entries.name: Lance
entries: {@i An ornate dragonlance shines among more ordinary weapons on a rack. The Lance card warns that healing sometimes requires additional injury, as when infection must be cut away.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A surgeon, or someone (such as a guard or soldier) who uses violence in pursuit of worthy societal goals.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature trained to fight alongside guards or soldiers.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where surgery is performed.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure made at great cost, or a magic weapon.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation in which additional pain is required to bring healing.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person committed to pacifism or avoiding harm,

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature uninterested in fighting, or a trap that restrains but doesn't cause damage.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where violence is forbidden.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure celebrating the end of hostilities or the ideal of peace, or a magic item intended to prevent or end conflict.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation complicated by people avoiding any hint of conflict.

entries.name: Mage
entries: {@i A warlock holds a black crystalline staff. This card suggests both mental acuity and arcane magic.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person (perhaps a sorcerer, warlock, or wizard) who uses arcane magic or other specialized learning.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature with abilities similar to those of a sorcerer, warlock, or wizard.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place dedicated to the study of arcane magic or that is suffused with such magic.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A magic item such as a wand or staff, or a wizard's spellbook.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that requires and rewards the correct use of arcane magic.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who wrongly believes their good luck is the result of innate magical ability or a magical good luck charm.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that resists or negates magic.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where magic has caused destruction, doesn't work (like the effect of an {@spell Antimagic Field}), or works unpredictably (perhaps triggering {@table Wild Magic Surge|PHB|wild magic surges}).

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object created by the use of magic, or a magic item with unpredictable effects (such as a {@item Wand of Wonder}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation caused by magic misused or out of control.

entries.name: Map
entries: {@i X marks the spot on an elaborate treasure map. The Map card provides guidance that leads to the goal of the quest.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who acts as a guide, showing the way forward.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that tracks by scent.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A path or road.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A valuable map (perhaps a jeweled globe or rare atlas), or a magic item that provides direction.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation best navigated with a guide.

items.name: Person
items.entry: Someone who tries to lead you on the wrong path.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature (such as a {@creature will-o'-wisp}) that leads travelers astray.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A demiplane or similar place that can't be found on maps, or a location hidden behind a secret door.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure from another plane of existence, or a magic item that creates or accesses an extradimensional space (like a {@item Portable Hole}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: No guide or direction is available.

entries.name: Maze
entries: {@i Unfortunate souls are trapped in an elaborate and impossible maze of cards. Those who draw the Maze card are lost.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who feels lost in their own life, unsure how to affect change, or a person with a wandering mind who takes their time getting to the point.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A minotaur or another creature that hunts in a maze or is imprisoned in a maze.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A maze, or a region (such as a forest or desert) where becoming lost is very easy.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting confusion or disorientation, or a magic item that can cause these states.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A confusing situation where it's difficult to perceive all the factors at play.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person running from expectations placed on them by family and society, trying to find a new path in life.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature whose behavior is unpredictable.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A simple labyrinth designed for meditation or to provide private nooks, or a location in which one is unlikely to get lost (such as a cave with only one exit).

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object incorporating a labyrinth design.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A search for something or someone that has gone missing.

entries.name: Mine
entries: {@i A well-crafted pick leans against a wall at the entrance to a mine. The Mine card represents something valuable underground or buried in the earth.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A miner or an archaeologist.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that burrows underground, especially one that delves into the earth in search of prey (such as a {@creature giant weasel}).

items.name: Place
items.entry: A mine, an archaeological dig, or a similar excavated site.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure from the earth, such as metal ore or gems, or any treasure that has been buried and unearthed.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Something unearthed that should have remained buried.

items.name: Person
items.entry: Someone who places things in the earth, such as a gardener or an undertaker.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that lives underground but hunts above ground (such as an {@creature ankheg} or a {@creature bulette}).

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place that has sunk into the earth, perhaps swallowed in a sinkhole or covered in a mudslide.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure buried in the earth.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: The retrieval of something buried.

entries.name: Monstrosity
entries: {@i An owlbear sits in a sunny glade. This card represents something monstrous, including familiar things that turn strange and threatening.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A familiar person whose behavior suddenly turns threatening.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Monstrosity, especially one that superficially resembles an ordinary animal or person (such as a {@creature displacer beast} or {@creature doppelganger}).

items.name: Place
items.entry: A familiar place that has become dangerous.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting a Monstrosity or that incorporates claws, fur, or feathers from such a creature.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation involving something or someone becoming more monstrous (literally or figuratively).

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who seems dangerous or bizarre but is friendly and helpful.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Monstrosity that is a potential ally, such as a {@creature hippogriff}.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place that offers refuge in unfamiliar or dangerous terrain.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A dead Monstrosity preserved by taxidermy, or a magic item useful against Monstrosities.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Something that appears monstrous but is actually benign.

entries.name: Moon
entries: {@i A crescent moon looms large in the autumn sky. The Moon card points to hidden potential.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: Someone whose fine qualities are masked by one annoying trait.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A lycanthrope, or a creature that appears to be an inanimate object until it strikes (such as a {@creature gargoyle}).

items.name: Place
items.entry: A secret chamber or a place concealed by terrain; alternatively, a place larger or more elaborate on the inside than it seems from outside.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure whose value isn't immediately apparent, or a magic item that appears to be a worthless object.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A problem that requires investigation and is more complicated than it appears.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who seems competent but bungles everything they attempt.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that uses its fearsome appearance to frighten away others because it is too weak to fight.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place with an impressive exterior but a dingy, poorly maintained interior.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure that seems more valuable than it is, perhaps an ordinary item that falsely appears magical.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that seems—and is—too good to be true.

entries.name: Ooze
entries: {@i A gelatinous cube with various items suspended inside it creeps through a vaulted sewer. The Ooze card indicates the importance of something that seems lowly or innocuous.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A quiet, unassuming person who has hidden power or secret knowledge.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: An Ooze or another creature that seems unimportant, or a trap that is surprisingly simple and straightforward.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A humble place of surprising comfort or importance.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure that is valuable but not beautiful, such as a poorly crafted piece of jewelry incorporating precious stones.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Something important that has been overlooked because it seems ordinary.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A quiet, unassuming person completely out of their depth.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: An Ooze that has develope curiosity, unexpected intelligence, and a way to communicate, or a dangerous trap that is difficult to detect.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A humble place with little to offer.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting an ooze or the destruction of a particularly notable Ooze; alternatively, a magic item useful against Oozes (such as a {@item Ring of Acid Resistance}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation complicated by the sheer number of minor factors tangled within it.

entries.name: Path
entries: {@i A well-worn path twists through the wilderness, with hidden dangers lurking in the shadows to both sides. This card suggests the importance of sticking with a plan and remaining focused on the destination.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A goal-oriented person who knows exactly what they want and has a clear plan to get it.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature single-mindedly pursuing prey or some other goal, or a trapped room navigable by only a single path.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A road or trail.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting a road or path, or a magic item that allows divination (such as a {@item Crystal Ball} or a {@item Spell Scroll (6th Level)|DMG|Spell Scroll} of {@spell Find the Path}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that demands unwavering focus on the goal.

items.name: Person
items.entry: An aimless person who doesn't know what they want and has no idea how to decide.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that reacts to provocation without a clear plan or purpose; it might be acting on instinct or be confused.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A trackless wilderness, or an underground complex that is very difficult to traverse.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An abstract art object, or a magic item that foils divination (such as an {@item Amulet of Proof against Detection and Location}).

items.name: Situation
